  <date name="Date:" role="creation">February 26, 2013–beginning; Today is November 30, 2018</date>
  <abstract name="Abstract.">
    <p>In this paper we propose and analyze a preconditioner for a system arising from a finite element
approximation of second order elliptic problems describing processes in
highly heterogeneous media.
Our approach uses the technique of multilevel methods (see,
e.g. <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="2008VassilevskiP-aa" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>) and the recently proposed
preconditioner based on additive Schur complement approximation by
J. Kraus (see, <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Kraus_12" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>). The main results are the design and a
theoretical and numerical justification of an iterative method for
such problems that is robust with respect to the contrast of the
media, defined as the ratio between the maximum and minimum values of
the coefficient (related to the permeability/conductivity).</p>
  </abstract>
  <keywords name="Key words and phrases">mixed finite elements, least-squares, high contrast media, robust preconditioners
for weighted <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\bm{H}}}({\operatorname{div}})" text="H * div" xml:id="m3">
      <XMath>
        <XMApp>
          <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>

            </XMWrap>
          </XMDual>
        </XMApp>
      </XMath>
    </Math>-norm, discrete Poincaré inequality</keywords>
  <classification name="1991 Mathematics Subject Classification" scheme="1991 Mathematics Subject Classification">65F10, 65N20, 65N30</classification>

    <title><tag close=". ">1</tag>Introduction</title>
    <toctitle><tag close=" ">1</tag>Introduction</toctitle>
    <para xml:id="S1.p1">
      <p>We consider the following second order elliptic
boundary value problem written in mixed form
for the unknown scalar functions <Math mode="inline" tex="p(x)" text="p * x" xml:id="S1.p1.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">p</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p1.m1.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p1.m1.1">x</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>
and the vector function <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\mathbf{u}}}" text="u" xml:id="S1.p1.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN">u</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>:</p>

      <p>Here, <Math mode="inline" tex="K:\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}" text="K colon R ^ d maps-to R ^ (d * d)" xml:id="S1.p1.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok name="colon" role="METARELOP">:</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="maps-to" name="mapsto" role="ARROW">↦</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                  <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">R</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                  <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">R</XMTok>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="times" role="MULOP">×</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is a
function taking values in symmetric,
positive definite (SPD) <Math mode="inline" tex="d\times d" text="d * d" xml:id="S1.p1.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">×</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> matrices for almost all <Math mode="inline" tex="x\in\Omega" text="x element-of Omega" xml:id="S1.p1.m5">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
              <XMTok name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN">Ω</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>.
The given forcing term <Math mode="inline" tex="f" text="f" xml:id="S1.p1.m6">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">f</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is function in <Math mode="inline" tex="L^{2}(\Omega)" text="L ^ 2 * Omega" xml:id="S1.p1.m7">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">L</XMTok>
                <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="2" role="NUMBER">2</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p1.m7.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p1.m7.1">Ω</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>,
<Math mode="inline" tex="\Omega\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}" text="Omega subset-of R ^ d" xml:id="S1.p1.m8">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="subset-of" name="subset" role="RELOP">⊂</XMTok>

              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> (<Math mode="inline" tex="d=2,3" text="d = list@(2, 3)" xml:id="S1.p1.m9">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="list"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.p1.m9.1"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.p1.m9.2"/>
                </XMApp>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok meaning="2" role="NUMBER" xml:id="S1.p1.m9.1">2</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                  <XMTok meaning="3" role="NUMBER" xml:id="S1.p1.m9.2">3</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>) is a bounded polyhedral
domain, and its boundary <Math mode="inline" tex="\partial\Omega" text="partial-differential@(Omega)" xml:id="S1.p1.m10">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="partial-differential" name="partial" role="OPERATOR">∂</XMTok>
              <XMTok name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN">Ω</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is split into two
non-overlapping parts <Math mode="inline" tex="\Gamma_{D}" text="Gamma _ D" xml:id="S1.p1.m11">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMTok name="Gamma" role="UNKNOWN">Γ</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">D</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> and <Math mode="inline" tex="\Gamma_{N}" text="Gamma _ N" xml:id="S1.p1.m12">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMTok name="Gamma" role="UNKNOWN">Γ</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">N</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>. In the case pure
Neumann problem, i.e. <Math mode="inline" tex="\Gamma_{N}=\partial\Omega" text="Gamma _ N = partial-differential@(Omega)" xml:id="S1.p1.m13">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok name="Gamma" role="UNKNOWN">Γ</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">N</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="partial-differential" name="partial" role="OPERATOR">∂</XMTok>
                <XMTok name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN">Ω</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, we assume that <Math mode="inline" tex="f" text="f" xml:id="S1.p1.m14">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">f</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>
satisfies the compatibility condition <Math mode="inline" tex="\int_{\Omega}fdx=0" text="(integral _ Omega)@(f * differential-d@(x)) = 0" xml:id="S1.p1.m15">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                  <XMTok mathstyle="text" meaning="integral" name="int" role="INTOP">∫</XMTok>
                  <XMTok fontsize="70%" name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN">Ω</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">f</XMTok>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok font="italic" meaning="differential-d" role="DIFFOP">d</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER">0</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>. In such a
case the solution is determined uniquely by taking <Math mode="inline" tex="\int_{\Omega}p~{}dx=0" text="(integral _ Omega)@(p * differential-d@(x)) = 0" xml:id="S1.p1.m16">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                  <XMTok mathstyle="text" meaning="integral" name="int" role="INTOP">∫</XMTok>
                  <XMTok fontsize="70%" name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN">Ω</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" rpadding="3.3pt">p</XMTok>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok font="italic" meaning="differential-d" role="DIFFOP">d</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER">0</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>.
To simplify our presentation, we shall assume that <Math mode="inline" tex="\Gamma_{D}" text="Gamma _ D" xml:id="S1.p1.m17">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
              <XMTok name="Gamma" role="UNKNOWN">Γ</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">D</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is an
non-empty set with strictly positive measure which is also closed
with respect to <Math mode="inline" tex="\partial\Omega" text="partial-differential@(Omega)" xml:id="S1.p1.m18">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="partial-differential" name="partial" role="OPERATOR">∂</XMTok>
              <XMTok name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN">Ω</XMTok>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, so the above problem
has unique solution <Math mode="inline" tex="p\in H^{1}(\Omega)" text="p element-of H ^ 1 * Omega" xml:id="S1.p1.m19">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">p</XMTok>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
                  <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.p1.m19.1"/>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                    <XMTok name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p1.m19.1">Ω</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>.</p>
    </para>
<!--  %**** String Line 150 **** -->    <para xml:id="S1.p2">
      <p>This equation is a model used for example in heat and mass
transfer, flows in porous media, diffusion of passive chemicals,
electromagnetics, and other applied areas.
Here we target applications of equations (<ref labelref="LABEL:equation-1"/>) - (<ref labelref="LABEL:N_BC"/>) to flows in <text font="italic">highly heterogeneous</text> media of high contrast.
This means that the coefficient <Math mode="inline" tex="K(x)" text="K * x" xml:id="S1.p2.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p2.m1.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p2.m1.1">x</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> represents media with
multiscale features, such as many inclusions where <Math mode="inline" tex="K(x)" text="K * x" xml:id="S1.p2.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p2.m2.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p2.m2.1">x</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> has small
values and long connected subdomains where <Math mode="inline" tex="K(x)" text="K * x" xml:id="S1.p2.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p2.m3.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p2.m3.1">x</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> has large values. An
important characteristic for such media is the contrast <Math mode="inline" tex="\kappa" text="kappa" xml:id="S1.p2.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" name="kappa" role="UNKNOWN">κ</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>,
defined by (<ref labelref="LABEL:contrast"/>). In the terminology of flows in porous
media the coefficient <Math mode="inline" tex="K(x)" text="K * x" xml:id="S1.p2.m5">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p2.m5.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p2.m5.1">x</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is called permeability and the unknown
variables <Math mode="inline" tex="p" text="p" xml:id="S1.p2.m6">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">p</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> and <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\mathbf{u}}}" text="u" xml:id="S1.p2.m7">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN">u</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> are called pressure and
velocity, respectively.</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S1.p3">
      <p>Flows in porous media appear in many industrial, scientific, engineering, and
environmental applications. One common characteristic of these diverse areas
of applications is that porous media are intrinsically multiscale and
typically display heterogeneities over a wide range of length-scales.
The computer generated permeability coefficient <Math mode="inline" tex="K(x)" text="K * x" xml:id="S1.p3.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p3.m1.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p3.m1.1">x</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> which exhibits such
features and is used in petroleum engineering simulations as a
benchmark is found in the SPE10 Project <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="SPE10_project" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>.</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S1.p4">
      <p>Depending on the application and its goals, solving the governing equations of flows in porous media might be sought at:
(a) a coarse scale (e.g., if only the global pressure drop for a given
flow rate is needed, and no other fine
<!--  %**** String Line 175 **** -->scale details of the solution are important),
or a coarse scale enriched with some desirable fine scale details, and
(b) the finest scale that resolves media heterogeneities, if computationally
this is possible.
The numerical solution of latter class of problems is a challenging task that has attracted a
substantial attention in the scientific and engineering community.</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S1.p5">
      <p>The aim of this paper is finite element approximations of the problem
(<ref labelref="LABEL:equation-1"/>) – (<ref labelref="LABEL:N_BC"/>) on a mesh that resolves the finest scale of
the permeability. This leads to a very large system of algebraic equations
and its efficient solution is the object of this paper. We give two finite element
approximations, dual mixed and least-squares FEM, and develop, study
and test an optimal (with respect to the contrast <Math mode="inline" tex="{\kappa}" text="kappa" xml:id="S1.p5.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" name="kappa" role="UNKNOWN">κ</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> and the mesh
size <Math mode="inline" tex="h" text="h" xml:id="S1.p5.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">h</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>) preconditioner for the corresponding algebraic problem.</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S1.p6">
      <p>The system arising from the finite element approximation
has symmetric matrix, which is indefinite in the case of a mixed method
and positive definite in the case of a least-squares approximation. In
both cases the preconditioner is a block diagonal matrix, which in
combination with a minimal residual method in the case of mixed method
and conjugate gradient iteration in the case of least-squares FEM,
leads to an optimal preconditioner so that the number of iterations
does not depend neither on the contrast nor on the mesh size.</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S1.p7">
      <p>In the least-squares methods written as a system of linear equations
<!--  %**** String Line 200 **** -->for the unknown <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\mathbf{u}}}" text="u" xml:id="S1.p7.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN">u</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math> and <Math mode="inline" tex="p" text="p" xml:id="S1.p7.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">p</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>, the upper left block (corresponding to
the vector variable <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\mathbf{u}}}" text="u" xml:id="S1.p7.m3">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN">u</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>) is a symmetric and positive definite matrix,
corresponding to the finite element approximation of the weighted
bilinear form <Math mode="inline" tex="(K^{-1}{{\mathbf{u}}},{{\mathbf{v}}})+({\operatorname{div}}{{\mathbf{u}}},{%&#10;\operatorname{div}}{{\mathbf{v}}})" text="open-interval@(K ^ (- 1) * u, v) + open-interval@(div@(u), div@(v))" xml:id="S1.p7.m4">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="plus" role="ADDOP">+</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="open-interval"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m4.2"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m4.1"/>
                </XMApp>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p7.m4.2">
                    <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                      <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="minus" role="ADDOP">-</XMTok>
                        <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                      </XMApp>
                    </XMApp>
                    <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN">u</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p7.m4.1">v</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
              <XMDual>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="open-interval"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m4.3"/>
                  <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m4.4"/>
                </XMApp>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p7.m4.3">
                    <XMTok role="OPFUNCTION" scriptpos="post">div</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN">u</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S1.p7.m4.4">
                    <XMTok role="OPFUNCTION" scriptpos="post">div</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN">v</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> with
<Math mode="inline" tex="{{\bm{H}}}({\operatorname{div}})" text="H * div" xml:id="S1.p7.m5">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="bold italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m5.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="OPFUNCTION" scriptpos="post" xml:id="S1.p7.m5.1">div</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>-conforming finite elements. For the mixed method this form
plays also essential role (see,
e.g. <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Arnold1997preconditioning" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>). It is known that the
preconditioner of Arnold, Falk, and Winther,
<cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Arnold1997preconditioning,Arnold2000MG" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>, is optimal if <Math mode="inline" tex="K(x)" text="K * x" xml:id="S1.p7.m6">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m6.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p7.m6.1">x</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>
is a constant matrix. However, since <Math mode="inline" tex="K(x)" text="K * x" xml:id="S1.p7.m7">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p7.m7.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S1.p7.m7.1">x</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> is the permeability of
heterogeneous media of high contrast, the corresponding matrix is very
ill-conditioned and consequently construction of an optimal
preconditioner is a nontrivial task.
The main result and novelty of this paper is design, theoretical justification, and
experimental study of a preconditioner for the matrix corresponding
to the above weighted bilinear form
that will produce an optimal iterative method which converges independently
of the contrast <Math mode="inline" tex="\kappa" text="kappa" xml:id="S1.p7.m8">
          <XMath>
            <XMTok font="italic" name="kappa" role="UNKNOWN">κ</XMTok>
          </XMath>
        </Math>. Such construction is based on the
method developed in <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Kraus_Lymb_Mar_2014" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite>.</p>
    </para>
    <para xml:id="S1.p8">
      <p>The paper is organized as follows. In Section <ref labelref="LABEL:sec:problem"/> the dual mixed and
least-squares variational formulations of the boundary value
problem (<ref labelref="LABEL:equation-1"/>)–(<ref labelref="LABEL:N_BC"/>) are given. Next we
introduce the weighted <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\bm{H}}}({\operatorname{div}})" text="H * div" xml:id="S1.p8.m1">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="bold italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p8.m1.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="OPFUNCTION" scriptpos="post" xml:id="S1.p8.m1.1">div</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math> bilinear form and show proper
inf-sup condition using the corresponding weighted norm. We emphasize
<!--  %**** String Line 225 **** -->that the constant in the inf-sup condition, coercivity and the
boundedness of the corresponding forms do not depend on the contrast
of the media defined by (<ref labelref="LABEL:contrast"/>).
In Section <ref labelref="LABEL:s:FEM"/> we introduce finite element approximations for the mixed and least-squared formulations. A key point in this part is Lemma <ref labelref="LABEL:lem:stab_fin"/>
where we establish an inf-sup condition
on a discrete level with a constant independent on the contrast. The detailed proof of the
Lemma is given in the Appendix. In Section <ref labelref="LABEL:s:precon"/>, which is central to the paper,
we describe the preconditioning method for the finite element systems.
Starting with the definition of a block-diagonal preconditioner for the dual-mixed formulation
in operator notation, see Section <ref labelref="LABEL:sec:b-diag-operator"/>, a reformulation of the FE problem
in matrix notation is given in Section <ref labelref="LABEL:sec:matrix-notation"/>.
The key issue in designing a contrast-independent Krylov solver becomes the construction
of a robust preconditioner for the weighted <Math mode="inline" tex="H({\operatorname{div}})" text="H * div" xml:id="S1.p8.m2">
          <XMath>
            <XMApp>
              <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S1.p8.m2.1"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="OPFUNCTION" scriptpos="post" xml:id="S1.p8.m2.1">div</XMTok>
                  <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMApp>
          </XMath>
        </Math>-norm. This is addressed in
details in Section <ref labelref="LABEL:sec:robust-H_div-precond"/> by, first, discussing an abstract auxiliary
space two-grid method, see Section <ref labelref="LABEL:sec:as-2-grid-precond"/>, and then, defining an
auxiliary space multigrid (ASMG) method, see Section <ref labelref="LABEL:sec:asmg"/>. Two variants of the
algorithm are described in Section <ref labelref="LABEL:sec:algorithms"/> differing only in the choice of the basis
in which smoothing and residual updates are performed. Finally, in Section <ref labelref="LABEL:sec:numerics"/>, we
present the numerical results for three different examples of porous media in two dimensions
in order to test the robustness of the preconditioner with respect to media contrast and its
optimality with respect to the mesh-size. All numerical results confirm our theoretical findings.</p>
    </para>
  </section>
  <section inlist="toc" labels="LABEL:sec:problem" xml:id="S2">
    <tags>
      <tag>2</tag>
      <tag role="refnum">2</tag>
      <tag role="typerefnum">§2</tag>
    </tags>
    <title><tag close=". ">2</tag>Problem formulation</title>
    <toctitle><tag close=" ">2</tag>Problem formulation</toctitle>
    <subsection inlist="toc" xml:id="S2.SS1">

        <tag>2.1</tag>

        <tag role="typerefnum">§2.1</tag>
      </tags>
      <title><tag close=". ">2.1</tag>Notation and preliminaries</title>
      <toctitle><tag close=" ">2.1</tag>Notation and preliminaries</toctitle>

        <p>For functions defined on <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\Omega}}" text="Omega" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m1">

          </Math> we shall use the standard notations for

          </Math>.

          </Math> we shall often use <Math mode="inline" tex="\|\cdot\|" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m12">

        <p>Occasionally, when we consider only a subset of <Math mode="inline" tex="\Omega" text="Omega" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m16">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN">Ω</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math>, say,
<Math mode="inline" tex="T\subset\Omega" text="T subset-of Omega" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m17">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="subset-of" name="subset" role="RELOP">⊂</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">T</XMTok>
                <XMTok name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN">Ω</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> we will indicate this in the notation for the norms
and seminorms, i.e., we have <Math mode="inline" tex="\|\cdot\|_{s,T}" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m18">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok meaning="parallel-to" name="||" role="VERTBAR">∥</XMTok>

                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m18.1">s</XMTok>

              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>,
<Math mode="inline" tex="\|\cdot\|_{s,\omega,T}" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m19">
            <XMath>

                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="omega" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m21.2">ω</XMTok>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p1.m21.3">T</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S2.SS1.p2">
        <p>In the following, if <Math mode="inline" tex="\omega\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}" text="omega element-of R ^ (d * d)" xml:id="S2.SS1.p2.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" name="omega" role="UNKNOWN">ω</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                  <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">R</XMTok>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="times" role="MULOP">×</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> is symmetric matrix,
the norm <Math mode="inline" tex="\|\omega\|_{\ell^{2}}" text="(norm@(omega)) _ (ell ^ 2)" xml:id="S2.SS1.p2.m2">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok meaning="norm"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p2.m2.1"/>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok meaning="parallel-to" name="||" role="VERTBAR">∥</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" name="omega" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p2.m2.1">ω</XMTok>
                    <XMTok meaning="parallel-to" name="||" role="VERTBAR">∥</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                  <XMTok fontsize="70%" name="ell" role="UNKNOWN">ℓ</XMTok>
                  <XMTok fontsize="50%" meaning="2" role="NUMBER">2</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> is, as usual, the spectral radius of
<Math mode="inline" tex="\omega" text="omega" xml:id="S2.SS1.p2.m3">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="omega" role="UNKNOWN">ω</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math>.

        <p>called the contrast of the media, is assumed that this could be many
orders of magnitude. For scalar permeability <Math mode="inline" tex="K(x)" text="K * x" xml:id="S2.SS1.p2.m4">

            </XMath>
          </Math>, obviously,

      </para>
      <para xml:id="S2.SS1.p3">
        <p>The Hilbert space <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\bm{H}}}({\operatorname{div}})" text="H * div" xml:id="S2.SS1.p3.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="bold italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>

                  <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p3.m1.1"/>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>

                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> consists of square-integrable
vector-fields on <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\Omega}}" text="Omega" xml:id="S2.SS1.p3.m2">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN">Ω</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> with square-integrable divergence. The inner product in
<Math mode="inline" tex="{{\bm{H}}}({\operatorname{div}})" text="H * div" xml:id="S2.SS1.p3.m3">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>

                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>

                            </XMDual>
                          </XMApp>
                          <XMDual>
                            <XMApp>
                              <XMTok meaning="list"/>
                              <XMRef idref="S2.E3.m1.4"/>
                              <XMRef idref="S2.E3.m1.5"/>
                              <XMRef idref="S2.E3.m1.6.2.1"/>
                            </XMApp>
                            <XMWrap>
                              <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER" xml:id="S2.E3.m1.4">0</XMTok>
                              <XMTok font="italic" name="quad" role="PUNCT"> </XMTok>
                              <XMText xml:id="S2.E3.m1.5">on</XMText>
                              <XMTok font="italic" name="quad" role="PUNCT"> </XMTok>
                              <XMApp xml:id="S2.E3.m1.6.2.1">
                                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                                <XMTok name="Gamma" role="UNKNOWN">Γ</XMTok>
                                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">D</XMTok>
                              </XMApp>
                            </XMWrap>
                          </XMDual>
                        </XMApp>
                        <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">}</XMTok>
                      </XMWrap>
                    </XMDual>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="PERIOD">.</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMath>
          </Math>
        </equation>
        <p>In the case when <Math mode="inline" tex="\Gamma_{D}=\emptyset" text="Gamma _ D = empty-set" xml:id="S2.SS1.p3.m6">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                  <XMTok name="Gamma" role="UNKNOWN">Γ</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">D</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="empty-set" name="emptyset" role="ID">∅</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> we have</p>
        <equation labels="LABEL:H-D-2" xml:id="S2.E4">
          <tags>
            <tag>(2.4)</tag>
            <tag role="refnum">2.4</tag>
          </tags>
          <Math mode="display" tex="H^{1}_{D}({{\Omega}})=\{\phi\in H^{1}({{\Omega}}):~{}~{}\int_{\Omega}\phi=0\}." text="(H ^ 1) _ D * Omega = conditional-set@(phi element-of H ^ 1 * Omega, (integral _ Omega)@(phi) = 0)" xml:id="S2.E4.m1">

        <p>Note that for <Math mode="inline" tex="\phi\in H^{1}_{D}({{\Omega}})" text="phi element-of (H ^ 1) _ D * Omega" xml:id="S2.SS1.p3.m7">

are in fact norms on <Math mode="inline" tex="H^{1}_{D}(\Omega)" text="(H ^ 1) _ D * Omega" xml:id="S2.SS1.p3.m10">

            </XMath>
          </Math> and we denote these norms
by

              </XMApp>

          </Math> and <Math mode="inline" tex="\|\phi\|_{1,\omega}" text="(norm@(phi)) _ (list@(1, omega))" xml:id="S2.SS1.p3.m12">

          </Math>.
The
space <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\bm{H}}_{\hskip-0.569055ptN}}({\operatorname{div}})" text="H _ N * div" xml:id="S2.SS1.p3.m13">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>

                </XMApp>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p3.m13.1"/>
                  <XMWrap>

                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> is defined as follows:</p>
        <equation labels="LABEL:H-N" xml:id="S2.E5">
          <tags>
            <tag>(2.5)</tag>
            <tag role="refnum">2.5</tag>
          </tags>
          <Math mode="display" tex="{{\bm{H}}_{\hskip-0.569055ptN}}({\operatorname{div}}):={{\bm{H}}_{\hskip-0.569%&#10;055ptN}}({\operatorname{div}};{{\Omega}})=\{{{\mathbf{v}}}\in{{\bm{H}}}({%&#10;\operatorname{div}};{{\Omega}}):~{}~{}{{\mathbf{v}}}(x)\cdot{{\mathbf{n}}}=0%&#10;\quad\text{on}\quad\Gamma_{N}\}." text="H _ N * div assign H _ N * list@(div, Omega) = conditional-set@(v element-of H * list@(div, Omega), (v * x) cdot n = list@(0, [on], Gamma _ N))" xml:id="S2.E5.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMDual>

                            </XMApp>
                            <XMWrap>
                              <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER" xml:id="S2.E5.m1.7">0</XMTok>

                              <XMText xml:id="S2.E5.m1.8">on</XMText>

                          </XMDual>

                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMath>
          </Math>
        </equation>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S2.SS1.p4">
        <p>Together with (<ref labelref="LABEL:H-div-prod"/>) the weighted inner product in the space <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\bm{H}}}({\operatorname{div}})" text="H * div" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="bold italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m1.1"/>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="OPFUNCTION" scriptpos="post" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m1.1">div</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>
will play a fundamental role in our analysis</p>
        <equation labels="LABEL:WH-div-prod" xml:id="S2.E6">
          <tags>
            <tag>(2.6)</tag>
            <tag role="refnum">2.6</tag>
          </tags>
          <Math mode="display" tex="\Lambda_{{\alpha}}({{\mathbf{u}}},{{\mathbf{v}}})=({{\alpha}}~{}{{\mathbf{u}}}%&#10;,{{\mathbf{v}}})+({\operatorname{div}}{{\mathbf{u}}},{\operatorname{div}}{{%&#10;\mathbf{v}}}),\quad\alpha(x)=K^{-1}(x)." text="formulae@(Lambda _ alpha * open-interval@(u, v) = open-interval@(alpha * u, v) + open-interval@(div@(u), div@(v)), alpha * x = K ^ (- 1) * x)" xml:id="S2.E6.m1">
            <XMath>

        </equation>
        <p>We also denote</p>
        <equation xml:id="S2.Ex2">
          <Math mode="display" tex="\|{{\mathbf{v}}}\|^{2}_{\Lambda_{\alpha}}=\Lambda_{{\alpha}}({{\mathbf{v}}},{{%&#10;\mathbf{v}}})=\|{{\mathbf{v}}}\|^{2}_{0,\alpha}+\|{\operatorname{div}}{{%&#10;\mathbf{v}}}\|^{2}." text="((norm@(v)) ^ 2) _ Lambda _ alpha = Lambda _ alpha * open-interval@(v, v) = ((norm@(v)) ^ 2) _ (list@(0, alpha)) + (norm@(div@(v))) ^ 2" xml:id="S2.Ex2.m1">

            </XMath>
          </Math>
        </equation>
        <p>Note, that a weighted bilinear form of the type <Math mode="inline" tex="\Lambda_{\alpha,\beta}({{\mathbf{u}}},{{\mathbf{v}}})=\alpha({{\mathbf{u}}},{{%&#10;\mathbf{v}}})+\beta({\operatorname{div}}{{\mathbf{u}}},{\operatorname{div}}{{%&#10;\mathbf{v}}})" text="Lambda _ (list@(alpha, beta)) * open-interval@(u, v) = alpha * open-interval@(u, v) + beta * open-interval@(div@(u), div@(v))" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m2">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="equals" role="RELOP">=</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                    <XMTok name="Lambda" role="UNKNOWN">Λ</XMTok>
                    <XMDual>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok meaning="list"/>
                        <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m2.1"/>
                        <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m2.2"/>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMWrap>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="alpha" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m2.1">α</XMTok>
                        <XMTok fontsize="70%" role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="beta" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m2.2">β</XMTok>
                      </XMWrap>
                    </XMDual>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMDual>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="open-interval"/>
                      <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m2.3"/>
                      <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m2.4"/>
                    </XMApp>
                    <XMWrap>
                      <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m2.3">u</XMTok>
                      <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m2.4">v</XMTok>
                      <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                    </XMWrap>
                  </XMDual>
                </XMApp>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="plus" role="ADDOP">+</XMTok>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" name="alpha" role="UNKNOWN">α</XMTok>
                    <XMDual>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok meaning="open-interval"/>
                        <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m2.5"/>
                        <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m2.6"/>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMWrap>
                        <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m2.5">u</XMTok>
                        <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m2.6">v</XMTok>
                        <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                      </XMWrap>
                    </XMDual>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" name="beta" role="UNKNOWN">β</XMTok>
                    <XMDual>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok meaning="open-interval"/>
                        <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m2.7"/>
                        <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m2.8"/>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMWrap>
                        <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                        <XMApp xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m2.7">
                          <XMTok role="OPFUNCTION" scriptpos="post">div</XMTok>
<!--  %**** String Line 325 **** -->                          <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN">u</XMTok>
                        </XMApp>
                        <XMTok role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                        <XMApp xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m2.8">
                          <XMTok role="OPFUNCTION" scriptpos="post">div</XMTok>
                          <XMTok font="bold" role="UNKNOWN">v</XMTok>
                        </XMApp>
                        <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                      </XMWrap>
                    </XMDual>
                  </XMApp>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>, with <Math mode="inline" tex="\alpha&gt;0" text="alpha &gt; 0" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m3">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="greater-than" role="RELOP">&gt;</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" name="alpha" role="UNKNOWN">α</XMTok>
                <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER">0</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> and <Math mode="inline" tex="\beta&gt;0" text="beta &gt; 0" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m4">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="greater-than" role="RELOP">&gt;</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" name="beta" role="UNKNOWN">β</XMTok>
                <XMTok meaning="0" role="NUMBER">0</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> constants, was
used by Arnold, Falk, and Winther in <cite class="ltx_citemacro_cite">[<bibref bibrefs="Arnold2000MG" separator="," yyseparator=","/>]</cite> to design
multigrid methods for <Math mode="inline" tex="{{\bm{H}}}({\operatorname{div}})" text="H * div" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m5">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="bold italic" role="UNKNOWN">H</XMTok>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m5.1"/>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="OPFUNCTION" scriptpos="post" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m5.1">div</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>-systems. A key moment in their
study was the construction of a multigrid method that converges
uniformly with respect to the parameters <Math mode="inline" tex="\alpha" text="alpha" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m6">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="alpha" role="UNKNOWN">α</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> and <Math mode="inline" tex="\beta" text="beta" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m7">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="beta" role="UNKNOWN">β</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math>. The
important difference between our bilinear form <Math mode="inline" tex="\Lambda_{\alpha}" text="Lambda _ alpha" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m8">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok name="Lambda" role="UNKNOWN">Λ</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="alpha" role="UNKNOWN">α</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>
compared with <Math mode="inline" tex="\Lambda_{\alpha,\beta}" text="Lambda _ (list@(alpha, beta))" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m9">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                <XMTok name="Lambda" role="UNKNOWN">Λ</XMTok>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMApp>
                    <XMTok meaning="list"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m9.1"/>
                    <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p4.m9.2"/>
                  </XMApp>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="alpha" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m9.1">α</XMTok>
                    <XMTok fontsize="70%" role="PUNCT">,</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" name="beta" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m9.2">β</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> is that in our form <Math mode="inline" tex="\alpha" text="alpha" xml:id="S2.SS1.p4.m10">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="alpha" role="UNKNOWN">α</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math>
is a highly heterogeneous function with high contrast.
This makes the proof of a proper <text font="italic">inf-sup</text> condition more delicate
and the construction of an efficient preconditioner more complicated.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S2.SS1.p5">
        <p>The main objective of this work is a derivation and theoretical justification
of numerical methods for solving the problem (<ref labelref="LABEL:equation-1"/>) –
(<ref labelref="LABEL:N_BC"/>)
that are robust with respect to the media contrast, or in the ideal case,
do not depend on the contrast
<Math mode="inline" tex="\kappa" text="kappa" xml:id="S2.SS1.p5.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" name="kappa" role="UNKNOWN">κ</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math>. In this regard, in the following we write <Math mode="inline" tex="x\lesssim y" text="x less-than-or-similar-to y" xml:id="S2.SS1.p5.m2">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="less-than-or-similar-to" name="lesssim" role="RELOP">≲</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">y</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> to
denote the existence of a constant <Math mode="inline" tex="C" text="C" xml:id="S2.SS1.p5.m3">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">C</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> such that <Math mode="inline" tex="x\leq Cy" text="x less= C * y" xml:id="S2.SS1.p5.m4">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="less-than-or-equals" name="leq" role="RELOP">≤</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">C</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">y</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>. In case
<Math mode="inline" tex="x\lesssim y" text="x less-than-or-similar-to y" xml:id="S2.SS1.p5.m5">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="less-than-or-similar-to" name="lesssim" role="RELOP">≲</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">y</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> and <Math mode="inline" tex="y\lesssim x" text="y less-than-or-similar-to x" xml:id="S2.SS1.p5.m6">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="less-than-or-similar-to" name="lesssim" role="RELOP">≲</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">y</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> we write <Math mode="inline" tex="x\eqsim y" text="x eqsim y" xml:id="S2.SS1.p5.m7">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok name="eqsim" role="RELOP">≂</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">y</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>. It is important
to remember that in our analysis the constants hidden in <Math mode="inline" tex="\lesssim" text="less-than-or-similar-to" xml:id="S2.SS1.p5.m8">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok meaning="less-than-or-similar-to" name="lesssim" role="RELOP">≲</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> or
<Math mode="inline" tex="\eqsim" text="eqsim" xml:id="S2.SS1.p5.m9">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok name="eqsim" role="RELOP">≂</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math> are always independent of the contrast and the mesh size.</p>
      </para>
      <para xml:id="S2.SS1.p6">
        <p>Note that for all <Math mode="inline" tex="\xi\in\mathbb{R}^{d}" text="xi element-of R ^ d" xml:id="S2.SS1.p6.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" name="xi" role="UNKNOWN">ξ</XMTok>
                <XMApp>
                  <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                  <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">R</XMTok>
                  <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
                </XMApp>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math>, <Math mode="inline" tex="x\in\Omega" text="x element-of Omega" xml:id="S2.SS1.p6.m2">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">x</XMTok>
                <XMTok name="Omega" role="UNKNOWN">Ω</XMTok>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> and writing <Math mode="inline" tex="K" text="K" xml:id="S2.SS1.p6.m3">
            <XMath>
              <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
            </XMath>
          </Math>
for <Math mode="inline" tex="K(x)" text="K * x" xml:id="S2.SS1.p6.m4">
            <XMath>
              <XMApp>
                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
                <XMDual>
                  <XMRef idref="S2.SS1.p6.m4.1"/>
                  <XMWrap>
                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.SS1.p6.m4.1">x</XMTok>
                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                  </XMWrap>
                </XMDual>
              </XMApp>
            </XMath>
          </Math> we have</p>
        <equationgroup class="ltx_eqn_eqnarray" xml:id="Ax1.EGx2">
          <equation xml:id="S2.Ex4">
            <MathFork>
              <Math tex="\displaystyle\|K^{-1}\|_{\ell^{2}}(K\xi\cdot\xi)\geq(\xi\cdot\xi)\|K^{-1}\|_{%&#10;\ell^{2}}\inf_{\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{(K\theta\cdot\theta)}{(\theta%&#10;\cdot\theta)}=(\xi\cdot\xi)\,\|K^{-1}\|_{\ell^{2}}\inf_{\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d%&#10;}}\frac{(\theta\cdot\theta)}{(K^{-1}\theta\cdot\theta)}=(\xi\cdot\xi)\|K^{-1}%&#10;\|_{\ell^{2}}\frac{1}{\|K^{-1}\|_{\ell^{2}}}=(\xi\cdot\xi)." text="(norm@(K ^ (- 1))) _ (ell ^ 2) * ((K * xi) cdot xi) &gt;= (xi cdot xi) * (norm@(K ^ (- 1))) _ (ell ^ 2) * (infimum _ (theta element-of R ^ d))@(((K * theta) cdot theta) / (theta cdot theta)) = (xi cdot xi) * (norm@(K ^ (- 1))) _ (ell ^ 2) * (infimum _ (theta element-of R ^ d))@((theta cdot theta) / ((K ^ (- 1) * theta) cdot theta)) = (xi cdot xi) * (norm@(K ^ (- 1))) _ (ell ^ 2) * (1 / (norm@(K ^ (- 1))) _ (ell ^ 2)) = xi cdot xi" xml:id="S2.Ex4.m4">

                  <td align="right"><Math mode="inline" tex="\displaystyle\|K^{-1}\|_{\ell^{2}}(K\xi\cdot\xi)" text="(norm@(K ^ (- 1))) _ (ell ^ 2) * ((K * xi) cdot xi)" xml:id="S2.Ex3.m1">
                      <XMath>
                        <XMApp>

                  <td align="center"><Math mode="inline" tex="\displaystyle\geq" text="&gt;=" xml:id="S2.Ex3.m2">
                      <XMath>
                        <XMTok meaning="greater-than-or-equals" name="geq" role="RELOP">≥</XMTok>
                      </XMath>
                    </Math></td>
                  <td align="left"><Math mode="inline" tex="\displaystyle(\xi\cdot\xi)\|K^{-1}\|_{\ell^{2}}\inf_{\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}%&#10;\frac{(K\theta\cdot\theta)}{(\theta\cdot\theta)}" text="(xi cdot xi) * (norm@(K ^ (- 1))) _ (ell ^ 2) * (infimum _ (theta element-of R ^ d))@(((K * theta) cdot theta) / (theta cdot theta))" xml:id="S2.Ex3.m3">

        <p>Based on this, without loss of generality we assume that
the following inequality holds</p>
        <equation labels="LABEL:bound_below_K" xml:id="S2.E7">
          <tags>
            <tag>(2.7)</tag>
            <tag role="refnum">2.7</tag>
          </tags>
          <Math mode="display" tex="(\xi\cdot\xi)\leq(K(x)\xi\cdot\xi),\quad\xi\in\mathbb{R}^{d}." text="formulae@(xi cdot xi less= (K * x * xi) cdot xi, xi element-of R ^ d)" xml:id="S2.E7.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S2.E7.m1.2"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMDual xml:id="S2.E7.m1.2">
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="formulae"/>
                      <XMRef idref="S2.E7.m1.2.1"/>
                      <XMRef idref="S2.E7.m1.2.2"/>
                    </XMApp>
                    <XMWrap>
                      <XMApp xml:id="S2.E7.m1.2.1">
                        <XMTok meaning="less-than-or-equals" name="leq" role="RELOP">≤</XMTok>
                        <XMDual>
                          <XMRef idref="S2.E7.m1.2.1.1"/>
                          <XMWrap>
                            <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                            <XMApp xml:id="S2.E7.m1.2.1.1">
                              <XMTok name="cdot" role="MULOP">⋅</XMTok>
                              <XMTok font="italic" name="xi" role="UNKNOWN">ξ</XMTok>
                              <XMTok font="italic" name="xi" role="UNKNOWN">ξ</XMTok>
                            </XMApp>
                            <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                          </XMWrap>
                        </XMDual>
                        <XMDual>
                          <XMRef idref="S2.E7.m1.2.1.2"/>
                          <XMWrap>
                            <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                            <XMApp xml:id="S2.E7.m1.2.1.2">
                              <XMTok name="cdot" role="MULOP">⋅</XMTok>
                              <XMApp>
                                <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                                <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
                                <XMDual>
                                  <XMRef idref="S2.E7.m1.1"/>
                                  <XMWrap>
                                    <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                                    <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.E7.m1.1">x</XMTok>
                                    <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                                  </XMWrap>
                                </XMDual>
                                <XMTok font="italic" name="xi" role="UNKNOWN">ξ</XMTok>
                              </XMApp>
                              <XMTok font="italic" name="xi" role="UNKNOWN">ξ</XMTok>
                            </XMApp>
                            <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                          </XMWrap>
                        </XMDual>
                      </XMApp>
                      <XMTok role="PUNCT" rpadding="10.0pt">,</XMTok>
                      <XMApp xml:id="S2.E7.m1.2.2">
                        <XMTok meaning="element-of" name="in" role="RELOP">∈</XMTok>
                        <XMTok font="italic" name="xi" role="UNKNOWN">ξ</XMTok>
                        <XMApp>
                          <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                          <XMTok font="blackboard" role="UNKNOWN">R</XMTok>
                          <XMTok font="italic" fontsize="70%" role="UNKNOWN">d</XMTok>
                        </XMApp>
                      </XMApp>
                    </XMWrap>
                  </XMDual>
                  <XMTok role="PERIOD">.</XMTok>
                </XMWrap>
              </XMDual>
            </XMath>
          </Math>
        </equation>
        <p>As seen from the considerations above, such an assumption is always
fulfilled if we scale the coefficient and work with</p>
        <equation xml:id="S2.Ex5">
          <Math mode="display" tex="K(x)\leftarrow K(x)\left\|\|K^{-1}(x)\|_{\ell^{2}}\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\Omega)}." text="K * x leftarrow K * x * (norm@((norm@(K ^ (- 1) * x)) _ (ell ^ 2))) _ (L ^ infinity * Omega)" xml:id="S2.Ex5.m1">
            <XMath>
              <XMDual>
                <XMRef idref="S2.Ex5.m1.5"/>
                <XMWrap>
                  <XMApp xml:id="S2.Ex5.m1.5">
                    <XMTok name="leftarrow" role="ARROW">←</XMTok>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
                      <XMDual>
                        <XMRef idref="S2.Ex5.m1.2"/>
                        <XMWrap>
                          <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                          <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.Ex5.m1.2">x</XMTok>
                          <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                        </XMWrap>
                      </XMDual>
                    </XMApp>
                    <XMApp>
                      <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                      <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
                      <XMDual>
                        <XMRef idref="S2.Ex5.m1.3"/>
                        <XMWrap>
                          <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                          <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.Ex5.m1.3">x</XMTok>
                          <XMTok role="CLOSE" stretchy="false">)</XMTok>
                        </XMWrap>
                      </XMDual>
                      <XMApp>
                        <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post2"/>
                        <XMDual>
                          <XMApp>
                            <XMTok meaning="norm"/>
                            <XMRef idref="S2.Ex5.m1.5.1"/>
                          </XMApp>
                          <XMWrap>
                            <XMTok role="VERTBAR" stretchy="true">∥</XMTok>
                            <XMApp xml:id="S2.Ex5.m1.5.1">
                              <XMTok role="SUBSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                              <XMDual>
                                <XMApp>
                                  <XMTok meaning="norm"/>
                                  <XMRef idref="S2.Ex5.m1.5.1.1"/>
                                </XMApp>
                                <XMWrap>
                                  <XMTok meaning="parallel-to" name="||" role="VERTBAR">∥</XMTok>
                                  <XMApp xml:id="S2.Ex5.m1.5.1.1">
                                    <XMTok meaning="times" role="MULOP">⁢</XMTok>
                                    <XMApp>
                                      <XMTok role="SUPERSCRIPTOP" scriptpos="post3"/>
                                      <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN">K</XMTok>
                                      <XMApp>
                                        <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="minus" role="ADDOP">-</XMTok>
                                        <XMTok fontsize="70%" meaning="1" role="NUMBER">1</XMTok>
                                      </XMApp>
                                    </XMApp>
                                    <XMDual>
                                      <XMRef idref="S2.Ex5.m1.4"/>
                                      <XMWrap>
                                        <XMTok role="OPEN" stretchy="false">(</XMTok>
                                        <XMTok font="italic" role="UNKNOWN" xml:id="S2.Ex5.m1.4">x</XMTok>
